Monday evening. March 20th 1933
Darling Lafern:

  We have had a gale all day and the wind is still blowing. I went out several times and picked up the King oranges that have blown off - got nearly a bushel, many weighing close to a pound. Wish you had them. I eat all I can, but there are many to give away.  They crack as they fall, then the ants and flies get into them in a short time and they are ruined. There is no sale for them. Those on the trees might as well be taken off - Do you want some?      My ankle is very sore this evening as I've pottered around such a lot today. Had a letter from Mrs Griffeth written from Glendale - a suburb of Los Angeles - four days after the quake. She was unhurt, but badly frightened. Friends of hers in Long Beach wrapped themselves in blankets and staid in autos on the mountainsides and haven't yet had their clothes off! These people couldn't go back to their apts until they had been inspected and pronounced safe, as the walls were cracked. I think I prefer to risk the hurricanes to the earthquakes! 
 So glad to get your letter yesterday. Thanks for the stamps. I laughed and laughed over the camel being urged uppty-up with the cheerful executioner waiting for him up at the top. I'm not a prohibitionist, and never was - wouldn't join the W.C.T.U. for I don't think you can legislate

2
people into being temperate. But I hate intemperance and always did and do not ever drink soft drinks, let alone hard ones. I think the 18th amendment has done worlds of harm, but I don't think things are going to be improved by repealing and selling the way it is being planned.   Government ownership and distribution under strict supervision is the only way to prevent the return of the evils of the saloon. I have just finished reading André Siegfried's America Comes of Age, and it is one of the most enlightening books I've ever read.  He starts in with the pioneering period, traces the streams of migration across the continent, the settlements of the different nationalities with their religious views, and shows how today the different parts of the U.S. still keep the religious and political as well as moral views that they have inherited from their old puritanical, Calvinistic forbears.   In the first part - the Ethnic Situatión  he tries to answer his own question Will America remain Protestant and Anglo Saxon, by discussing the melting pot, the religious aspect, puritan resistance to freedom of thought, the color problem, prohibition, race consciousness and eugenics, Ku Klux Klan, etc. Then he takes up the economic situation; the political situation and analyses the different parties, international relations, our antagonism to the yellow races, and our viewpoint as contrasted with that of Europe. I feel as tho I had spent some time in college, I've learned so much. I'd like now to read his analysis of the Depression, the failure of the financial system, etc if he ever writes one. He foretold

it all in one of his chapters.

Yes, I hope they will keep you so busy you won't be let off for a vacation without pay. 

  Our robins have left I think, as I've not seen any for several days. They seemed to enjoy picking the pulp out of the g.f. and oranges on the ground - and the way they ate the mulberries! and stained things up with their droppings! 
 It is a pity you can't take part in the socialist meetings but I think it would be unwise for you to do it. It is a great relief to have somebody doing something, as Roosevelt is. But I'm afraid he is only going to try patching up the old system, instead of building a new one. I notice in one of the papers I've read the past few days that somebody else has my idea of making the present banks all depositories of U.S. funds, and turning them into postal savings banks. There is going to be a big movement to have that done, and people won't be satisfied until it is done for everybody has lost confidence in the old banking system.
   It has begun to rain, and I'm glad that I'm going to celebrate by going to bed. 

Stacks of love, 
Mother.

2     1935
No, I was never at the Wenona fair. I think Woodford didn't join in, as we had good grounds and buildings for many years. The clock has struck eight. The paper has just come. I wanted to begin a chapter on my early political opinions, but it must wait. 
Jan.19.  So you attended a Townsend club meeting? I went to their district meeting Thursday afternoon out of curiosity, and took notes for Dr. Brewster.   He couldn't go. They say they have no intention of advocating a third party. They have the same tactic that Upton Sinclair employs - use old party candidates but get them to endorse their platform. Such things never work. An old time politician has too many Capitalist ideas firmly embedded in his brain cells to be able to keep his promises, even if he knows how to use his vote. I encourage the idea of pensions, not only for old people, but for everybody. I [unclear] the mere fact of getting together on an economic idea is a step ahead for many people, so I favor it, but I have not joined the club. 

  You have done much more writing for the public than I. I have written letters and diaries voluminously, but very little otherwise, and some of it is out of print. You seem more than ever like home folks - only please, don't get sentimental - when you mention the Wesleyan at Bloomington, only 16 miles from old Metamora. I have a very dear friend who lives now, and has for years in Normal. Had a letter this past week from her. She taught me music for several years. Yes, I recall the Overland Monthly and the Woman's Magazine and the Daily. I was in St. L. at the time of the Fair there and took my little daughter. We went to the development and heard the publisher - wasn't his name Lewis? - give an address. He was a clever schemer, but little more, and was on the decline at the time. Your thrill over the Lahore, India paper reminds me of one I had - an article which was syndicated in a Chicago paper was translated into Spanish for an educational monthly there, then re-translated into English and printed in some school paper here in the U.S. My father-in-law Prof. Alexander Kerr, who was professor emeritus at Wisconsin U. after teaching Greek there 39 years, found the article and gave me the copy. It has been lost in all these years of moving about, but the subject of the paper was teaching children by suggestion, and founded upon the experiences and successes I had with my own Katherine. I cured her of thumb-sucking as well as some other things. I'm glad you wrote for Daniel De Leon's N.Y. People

I used to read that paper. And B.O. Flowers' 'Arena' was finally merged with Mr Kerr's "New Occasions" to form "The New Time". I've entertained Mr Flower in our very modest home in a suburb of Chicago while the plans for the merger were taking place. 

 Yes, I'd like sometime to read some of your literary efforts, but not now. I have too little time to myself to really enjoy what I read, and in fact, I've read nothing but periodicals since I came here. 
  I heard Norman Thomas over WDAE before I got dinner and I heard President Roosevelt after, then Ray Chapman Andrews - whom I admire immensely - and Governor Lehman dedicate the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial in N.Y.C. Static is very bad today and listening is a punishment rather than a pleasure.  Thomas made a very fine talk, and his presence I hope will stimulate the Tampa people to demand prosecution of the sluggers. He could not include policies in his speech today, but he put in some big whacks against Capitalism.

Any word yet from Pater? Mrs. Schuler still in Miami?
Apr. 1938 
Monday 8:30 p.m.
Darling Tafern: Have just heard Big Ben in London strike half past two a.m. after having listened to a symphony of Hayden's in C.  no. 69.  Before that a men's chorus sang some college and nursery songs, followed by news from all over the world by a British broadcaster, using the peculiar accent Mr. Ingham used. It was quite an experience, for I had no program, but just tuned in and happened to get it by short wave.  My radio is an increasing joy, as you can imagine. 

 Well, I came home Friday afternoon by bus from St. Petersburg. I can't begin to tell you what a swell time I had. On the postal I sent you, I believe I told you how I got there, unexpectedly.  I took

As soon as my hat was off and my face washed, we began to chatter, and we kept it up as a lively rate all the time we were together. We went over all the Metamora people we could think of from our cradles up, until the present. I asked how much the rates were at that hotel and she said $3.00. I told her I could never pay that and that I would go out and hunt a cheaper place. But she wouldn't hear to it. She arranged with the management for a

The first evening, Wednesday, some friends of hers, who own the latest model Cadillac, took us our for a drive about the city, and I marvelled at the changes, and improvements in the city since I last saw it. Everything is done for the comfort, convenience and attraction of tourists. A million dollar recreation pier, many luxurious hotels, a yacht basin, swimming pools and beaches, and rooming places and eating houses by the thousands. Also souvenir shops, movie theatres, tennis and shuffle board courts, checker boards in the shade, amusement parks for band concerts

One of the outstanding things I saw was a private collection of shells from every coast in the world, housed in a large shop where curios and absurd articles made from shells were sold. I saw 300 lb conch shells from the Indian Ocean. I saw the shell of a snail that lives on trees in Brazil that closes a leaf like a nest, and lays an egg like a bird. vegetation while artificial Easter lilies were everywhere. We eat outside awhile, watching the crowds, then we went into a shop next door where candied fruits, souvenirs and postcards were sold. The next morning Nell and I got up early and went by street car nine miles to Gulfport where we had breakfast. I took fried fish and Nell took cakes and syrup. We went out on one of the piers where people were fishing, but not catching anything as it was terribly windy and the bay was very rough. We got back in time for me to catch the 10:45 bus for home, and regretfully said good bye. 
Sunday I ate dinner with the Lewistons, paid a short call on Mrs Campbell and she came home with me to hear the new radio. Later the Wrays came in and staid to hear Charlie McCarthy. Today I washed and had a long nap this afternoon. Was so glad to get your letter yesterday. Thanks for deposit slip

Avon Park
Sept. 10, 1939. 
Darling Tafern, Wish you were here for a good visit. I'm lonesome and no one to talk to. Had a disappointment today - A young woman, Mabel Seybert, operator in one of the beauty parlors, promised to come out this afternoon. She is a very nice young person, somewhat younger than you and I have had her out here a number of times. And six or seven times when I've planned for her she hasn't come. Today is one of them. I made sandwiches at Mrs L's before I left, and got a pint of ice cream on my way for refreshments. Called at her hotel and was told she had gone out; hadn't told where she was going but left word for anybody who called that she wasn't in.

Mrs.Raab manager of the hotel said she wasn't feeling just right. It may be family troubles. Her father, who used to be a singer in a troupe with Mme Shuman-Heink, is rather sporty, imbibes too freely at times and spends his money instead of handing it to Mabel's step-mother. He has been straight all summer. His wife went to the N.Y. fair and he came over from their home in Ft. Meade twice a week to see Mabel and she felt so happy that he was "straight". So if he has tanked up again she will be heartbroken. But I think she should have left a note at least to explain. I ate all the ice cream - 30 cents worth - and two cookies that Mrs. Walker, a neighbor of Mr's L's gave me.
We had a doctor for Mrs L. yesterday. He found a high blood pressure of 200 and a leaky mitral valve along with hardening of the arteries. We have been giving her bromides on his prescription, and she has been quieter today.

Feb. 16, 1940. 
Darling Tafern, How is the fruit? I hope it is satisfactory so you can get more orders. I had a card from J. F. today saying he intended to get some orders for me in a week or ten days. I wrote him to send them at once if possible as the trees are beginning to show new growth, and the fruit should be off. I am using the fruit right along and find no difference in it. If you have to lower the price in order to get orders, do so. I leave it to you. 

  Mrs Putney, my blind friend, is to come next Tuesday for several days for a change. Her old blind husband died the first of the month. His daughter came  from Mass. and was her yesterday

[written in left margin and at top of the letter]
Dearie, didn't I send you the film of the enlarged picture  of me that was snapped at Harder Hall? Please have a print made, as I want to send it to an old school friend.

Every Wednesday evening there is a lot of static so I can't hear the toothpaste program. I get a lot of pleasure listening a half-hour every week day to the School of the Air. I'm learning lots about folk-songs, explorations, "tales from far and near", etc. from 9:15 to 9:45 every morning. This aft. I listened to Damrosch's  music appreciation hour, which I've heard more or less often for several years. 
I hope your cold weather has moderated by this time. We have had the coldest winter here in 45 years, but the damage hasn't been so great as it was then, because the trees were dormant this time. Love to all, Mother.

May, 1940 Mothers Day-
Avon Park
Darling Tafern, 
The dear little Kindergartenish card came two days ago and it brought up many memories. Thanks for it very much. Today is very beautiful, a little cool for us - 63º - after the very much needed showers we had yesterday. I've had my breakfast, whole wheat bread, soft egg, strawberries and cambric tea, washed my few dishes, swept the back porch and brushed the cat. Only I brushed her first, then swept out the cat hairs. She slept there all night, contrary to our usual custom. It was so dark when I put her out that I couldn't see whether or not she went out. She is to be confined in about three weeks, and her appetite is

A fine thing to read on Mother's Day  This morning the first thing I did after I was dressed was to read Thanatopsis aloud to myself.  at noon I heard Ted Malone tell about Bryant's home in Mass. and hear him read Thanatopsis as the ending of his program.  To me it has always been a wonderful poem.  I've tried to memorize it, but my brain cells are too hardened, they resist it.  But I keep it handy where I can read it occasionally.

  What has become of Orson Welles?  I miss hearing him.  -  -  -  -
  Two or three more broadcasts of news, including Kaltenborn, and some very good music over C.BS.  Now nearly time for Charley MacCarthy.  Reception very good today.  When we were out walking there wasn't a cloud in the sky.

7:30   couldn't get all of the bubble gum talk - static increasing.   Much love to all,   Mom

Last Sunday most of this same crowd of friends had a picnic - I was included - on another abandoned farm in the direction of Wauchula. We saw several other abandoned farms, or groves in that section too. A big rain came up and we rushed to the home of some of the party, Mr. and Mrs. Davis, who are struggling to make a living keeping bees. They have tried cattle, chickens, trucking, by turns and now have bees. Mrs. Davis used to be a crack stenographer in N.Y.C. later in the crate mills here. Has lost a thumb  by infection, and is now too old to get another position. And she is worn out by hard work on the farm. It is quite pathetic. She is a fine, earnest, honest woman, a Catholic, and I like her very much. Guess I've mentioned her before. Her husband is also hard-working,  been a soldier in the Phillipines

and was born and brought up near White Water Falls, and still owns - or Mrs D does - a farm near Walhalla. We are all readers of the Am. Guardian, so you can see why we are good friends. I have been trying to get up a club of yearly subscribers lately and I wrote cousin Carrie to send me a dollar to renew the sub. I donated to them some years ago. Had a letter from her Sat. enclosing the dollar. The American Guardian is one of the few weeklies that is standing out against the war, so I am especially anxious to help keep it going. I am glad you can do something to show which side you are on. I don't think any of us will succeed in doing anything more than that, for no matter who is elected I think they will drag us in after election. There won't be any Imperialist power to defend pretty soon, except Hitler's so the candidates can safely promise not to send our boys to Europe. But I notice the Conscription Bill says Hemispheric, so they will find plenty of places for them to go.

I am glad you were pleased to have the pin and the dishtowels. I didn't make the holder. It is one of two that Mrs. Griffith knit for me. I don't use my eyes for fancy work any more for, as you say, it is harder on them than reading. I have heard Mother say that reading was harder on her eyes than needle work, so I guess the thing is hardest that you were least accustomed to when you began to learn to do anything. Thanks for the copies of P.M. but don't send any more. I get the news from Time and the New Masses and the Guardian, and people keep giving me books to read, so I have more than I can manage. I was glad to see what kind of a paper it is. Mrs. Shockley gave me H.G. Wells' The Fate of Man to read. Max ought to get it form the library. I recall how much he admires Wells. I sent Marvin a card, and he replied promptly with one that is very pretty, a trail through the pines.

Mrs. May Walden
420 West Bell Street, Box 853
Avon Park, Fla.
5 a.m. Sunday, August 28, 1940
Darling Tafern:
Never was check more welcome! I hadn't had a penny in my purse for three days, and Foster's rent due, but hasn't paid yet. He came to apologize for forgetting, made a date when he would pay, and haven't seen him since. His wife and baby went a week ago to visit her mother. Maybe he has gone after them. So you see how welcome the check was. It was spent except for 42 c[ents] in a few minutes, as I needed kerosene and groceries. Byrum took me to Sebring one day last week where I applied for Old Age Assistance. But they are now just taking up applications of last Nov. and Dec. So I expect to be an angel and with the angels stand before my remittance arrives. Hope your father gets his. They pay $40.00 in Calif. I will get $11.29 or some such magnificent sum. But anything will help.
I wonder if Rose and Charles Lewiston have called?

Aron Park _ Jan 10th. 1941
Professor John J. Seammons,
Living Literature, W.R.U.W. Boston, Mass.
Dear Sir,
I listened with much interest last evening to your talk on Living Literature. I have for years looked out of my windows and have seen beautiful things made more beautiful by the varied changes of the seen light and shadows on vines and trees and clouds. I look on my mantle, and see an old pewter mug with a glass bottom that brings to mind an old English gentleman who gave it to me, and who taught me to appreciate Art in many forms, and to see beauty in many things, hitherto unsuspected of me. 
The old pewter mug, not kept bright and shiny, but tarnished by years of service, was given as a prize to this man- he was proud of his Irish ancestry and insisted upon being called Shammus, which he said means James- for winning a rowing contest on the Thames and, he said, was presented by Charles Dickens.

I took that with a grain of salt and looked up Dickens' dates, which are 1812 and 1870. I reminded him that he was 30 years old when Dickens died and that when he, Shammus, was an English school boy, say 16 or 17 that Dickens would hardly be presenting trophies to winners of rowing matches. He quickly and adroitly rejoined that it was Charlie Dickens, the son of the great novelist. Whether or not Dickens had a namesake son I never found out, but anyway there is the pewter mug with a glass bottom, which Shammus said was the way drinking cups were made at that time and that fact gave rise to the common Irish toast, "Here's lookin' at you!"
Copied and mailed to Prof. John J. Seammon, to W.R.U.W. Boston, Mass. 1-10-41.

May 18, 1941. Just Read a letter from E Harriett Donlevy Cors Sec. for the World Wide Broadcasting Foundation telling me Professor Scammell after 5 months, had turned my letter over to these to answer. I have no glass-bottom mugs, but several small mugs and a communion cup and chalice. Please don't question too much the Charlie Dickens story of your good friend Sheammus- it adds such flavor to the cup". Mrs. May Walden
420 WEST BELL STREET, BOX 853
AVON PARK, FLA.
June 23, 1942
Darling Tafern,
Have just reread your last letter and I can't tell you the pleasure it has given me. So sorry you had to write it long hand at home after having been up late the night before. You described everything so vividly that I could see it all. Am hoping the draft board sees the necessity of Marvin's deferment. Please let me know. I'm interested in every detail you write about any of you. So hungry to hear about everything. When you think of it, I'd be glad of another personel sheet, and that letter of your father's with the item about Russia. This is Russian War Relief Week. I sent to Miami to a branch of the RWR. committee for information as to their activities, and
in left margin and across top                       
So happy over Sam's gift to Marvin!  
Hope Marvin writes to me as he feels like it Malcom and I have much in common over Russia.

Darling Tafern
On page 32 of Time for June about A Lover and His Lass that I hope you will read. Buy a copy if you can't get it at the library. The story tells about the 6th Marquess of Northhampton of Castle Ashley (you recalled Mr. Ingham always pronounced it Castle Ashby) and his new bride. Can't tell you how delighted I was to get your letter telling about Marvin's work hours, address, presents and so on- When my brains don't feel baked, as they do now, I will write to him. Yesterday the mercury stood at 96 for several hours. Then a fine big thunder storm came up and cooled us off (75 now.) about all I did, after getting and frying a nice mullet for my dinner, was to read, nap and fan.

Darling Tafern

 It's been too hot to write lately. Now, after a good cooling off in the but, and a breeze blowing, maybe even at 92 [degrees] I can manage without sticking to the desk, the paper, and everything else.  I find it lots hotter in this little old camp-cottage than in the stucco and plastered bungalow.  But - there's the money, so why complain?
 Have just made out an order to Sears, Roebuck for goods for 3 thin dresses. I'm almost all out of thin dresses. Tried one on at Mrs. Otis' this morning (3.950 but it was too small. I get the goods for 3 for $3.56 and

on side:  thunder shower coming. Do you handle air-plane insurance? I think that a greater menace here than hurricanes. I don't mean insurance from bombing,
but from practice planes. Miss Voght was telling me about it this a.m.   Ate a pound of big fat sweet cherries for my lunch - Beginning to feel hungry.
Much love to all.   Mother

Mrs. May Walden
420 West Bell Street, Box 853
Avon Park, Fla.
Saturday afternoon
Darling Tafern,
The hair nets and two dollars came with your letter this morning. Many thanks. The nets will last quite awhile ( I hope). I'm sure to catch them in the trees when I got out in the grove if I don't have a rag tied over my head. So I try to be careful. I'm sending back one of the dollars for a birthday present for Maxine. Think you will have time to get something. I suggest kindergarten sewing cards, or building blocks - something to occupy busy little hands and train little muscles so they will be skillful as she grows up. Allthea could sew on buttons, and I think you could too, at her age.

The art of swabbing snuff is something like this: You open your mouth throw your head back, then pour from a highly decorated tin box or can, a mouthful of delicious, fragrant snuff. Mrs. May Walden
420 West Bell Street, Box 853
Avon Park, Fla. 
7:30 p.m.
Thursday Nov. 26, 1942
Darling Tafern,
Just home from an all day visit at the Wray's. We had roast rabbit, dressing, mashed potatoes and cranberry sauce, string beans, baked apples & pumpkin pie. Mildred had to work from 12 to 5, so we didn't eat the turkey until after she came. The dressing was terribly salty, the beans not salty enough. The pumpkin custard was good, but the crust was tough. I ate a big dinner notwithstanding. I hemmed up a brown velvet dress for Mildred and did a little darning for myself. A near neighbor, Mrs Weisheyer and her married daughter, Dorothy, came in this afternoon and we had a pleasant visit. This was before our dinner. I called on my renter in the garage apt. last evening and he promised to help me out in the picking. I telephoned the express office and find the cost of shipping is 10 cents more a bushel than last year and the express to Milwaukee is $1.70 I telephoned Byrum this aft. and he said the price of fruit to be 25 cents more a bushel than last year. So

Friday 9 a.m. Am refreshed and ready for whatever comes today. Had no nap yesterday aft. so I was needing the sleep. Forgot to thank you for the dollar. I paid it out at once to have my white shoes half-soled. The cobbler told me that soon there will be no more leather for half-soles, which is a pleasant prospect. I've barefooted in the house all summer, but to go out-doors with sand-spurs threatening every step, isn't. Frank has given up the 3 month's stay with me this winter because he has so much watch work on hand, and impossible to get materials promptly. Am looking forward to those pictures. Am making a scrap book out of old gift cards for Maxine. Love to all. Mother.

Avon Park, Fla.
Yesterday morning wen I was washing, Cora and Mildred Wray stopped their car out in front and told me that Mildred and Frank were married last Friday evening. They went to Wauchula, and didn't let Cora know anything about it. I'm glad they did, for Cora was so determined that Mildred shouldn't marry until she menstruates. But the poor young-one never will. She was 29 yesterday and Cora has been taking her to a Sebring M.D. to have her vulva stretched, as she is just like a little girl. But, even if she never can have sexual contact, she can love her man and he can love her, and I'm glad she had spunk enough to defy her mother. She is self-supporting, and works hard, with long hours and, I think, deserves to do as she pleases.

Mrs. May Walden 
420 West Bell Street, Box 853
Avon Park, Fla. 
April 26, 1943.
Darling Lafern,

 I'm trying to write some letters this afternoon, and am enclosing the ones I've answered.  
 Yesterday was cold and windy, though sunshiny. Instead of my Easter outfit, I wore the grey crêpe you gave me last year, as it has long sleeves, and my winter coat. Byrum Shockley came for me and we carried the box of his mother's clothing out to Mrs. Putney, who is the same size Mrs. S- was. He brought the things in several days ago and I washed and ironed some, darned and mended all. After a short visit we went on to Highlands Lakes and spent several hours with the German refugees. The Hendricks, who lived first in my house before they bought this stucco house out there. They have repaired and improved the place, put up a nice 

to go to Chicago to get watch material. Love to all, Mother.

garage, put in a fine solar heat system, built on a fine front porch screened in, have a lovely bird bath of concrete, etc. etc. They are interned, so they can't drive to Frostproof or Sebring, can't have a radio or a camera, etc. etc. until they get their final citizenship papers, which is two or three years off. But they are making the best of it and are working bravely to make a nice home. The house next to me rented to the Wells's is sold and they have to find another - which is an impossibility at present. Am sorry to lose them. They are fine neighbors. Mr. Wells boxed up my radio yesterday and today, after I had finished my washing, Mrs. Johnson and Mrs. Gatlin came along to take me to town. So we took the radio and expressed it to Atlanta so Sears Rbuck can re-condition it. The ladies will be leaving soon for N.J. Then I'll be lonesome for sure. Wonder if you had your visit with Martha? Tafern Dearie, tell me what is a zook suit? [zoot?] Heard Baukhagr discuss the situation in Los Angeles, and he said the disturbance is more a psychological one than anything else - a clash between races where one race that previously had nothing and is now well paid (Mexican and Negroes) is bullying the white race (the service men) which resents it. 420 West Bell Street, Box 853
Avon Park, Fla. 
5 a.m.
Nov. 8, 1943
Darling Tafern:
So happy that you made the convention, and I appreciate the effort you made to write me in long hand when you might have been sight seeing. No, I never visited the Capital building. I saw it, and also the tomb - or monument - from a distance but not as I wanted to. The times I was there I was busy with other matters. The first time I was organizing the coal miners for the Socialist Party and the miners weren't interested in a pile of marble. They were eager for me to meet a young fellow - Johnnie Lewis (John L. Lewis) who was a hero in their eyes, and who was "going to be a big name some day". But Johnnie was out of town just then, so I missed him. The second time I was a delegate from the S.P. to a convention of the State (maybe Nat'l, I forget which) Federation of Women's Clubs. I had a paper to read on the Socialist attitude 
I've knitted a pair of bed socks for Maxine - Please let me know how they fit. They're an un-Christmas present.

Darling Tafern:
The beautiful book ends were in the office Monday afternoon and I taxied home with them at once. They were beautifully and artistically packed, tied with wide white ribbon in a big rosette - all that anyone could desire for a Mother's Day present. Thankyou very, very much. But they are not bears, my darling. They are tigers, but they will hold he books just as firmly. I called [Vadeen?] to look before I unwrapped them as they looked so pretty. The blood sweating behemoth, Messerschmidt, has been given an inferiority complex by his son Elmer. Both wanted to be husbands to Midge, but Messer had to retire. It didn't do Elmer any good thought for Midge hates him and fought him off. Her favors went to Mrs. Godwin's old yellow alley cat. So about July 16th I'll be drowning kittens again. I've a notion to 
bound to be read now that Boston has censored it. Miss Smith says she is sorry, because low-minded readers would be attracted to it in the expectation of finding pornographic, but she says they will be disappointed. This gives you a membership in he Book Find Club. Saw "North Star" twice. A wonderful picture, am going to dentist this aft. then to see "The City that stopped Hitler" The Catholic church forbids its members from seeing "Lost Angel".

Mrs. May Walden
420 West Bell Street, Box 853
Avon Park, Fla.
June 10, 1944.
Darling Tafern:
I'm wondering if you are having as hot weather there as we are having here. We've had very little rain and I've had to water my plants every night but two since you left. I had Mrs. Putney here for her birthday on the 6th, and Mrs. Weatherly came in to eat with us, and I used the new yellow table linen. It is very attractive and everyone praises it. Mrs. Putney could feel of it and decided it was of very superior quality. She used to be employed in a London textile house when she was a young woman. She asked me to tell you how much she appreciated your lovely letter (she brought it with her for me to read, and expected to have me answer it for her, but her brother insisted upon answering it before she could come in) and how much she enjoyed your visit. She is sure you are a very fine woman, and I told her you certainly are. I had chicken, lots of gravy, b&b, peas, tomato salad, and tapioca cream.

Mr. J.'s vexations are only a sample of what all American housewives, who live near army camps are subject to, so it will be wonderful relief when the soldiers wives are back in their own household and have to clean up after themselves and their dirty young ones. I get on very well with my couple. They go before seven and don't get back until 6:30. It is rather troublesome on their one day off each week when Lucille washes and irons. This week I had to make blueberry muffins for my dinner when she had 6 dresses plus a lot of other things to iron, and she was considerably in my way. She apologized, and I responded amiably, so we got on o.k. My worst complaint is the cigarette smoke they both make when they are home, and the fact that neither of them clean out the wash basin or the bath tub after using them - I've put up with it so far without murmuring, but it's hard on me to clean the bath tub. I'm getting too stiff in my knees to wait on younger people. They take me to town whenever I'm ready to go when they go, and they bring my mail. So I try to think things are even. I'm expecting letters from all of you soon. Miss Jenther will not be home again. Cancer. Much love to all, Mother.

Mrs. May Walden
420 West Bell Street, Box 853
Avon Park, Fla.
June 18, 1944 -
Darling Tafern:
Your letter acknowledging the $50. reached me this morning. I didn't go in town yesterday as it was so hot, but Lucille Wells brought it when she came home from breakfast. I seem to have anticipated your wish in my last letter, but I didn't write anything of your father's early life. Perhaps you may not recall that his parents were both teachers who zealously favored education for the Negroes, so after their marriage they came to Georgia and were teaching when the Civil War broke out. I forget the name of the town where he was born, but he was very young when his parents had to escape to the North and were the last people to get through the lines before communications ceased. They then taught in different towns near Rockford, in Ill and Wisc. finally settling in Madison - I can't recall where Jamie was born, nor do I know the year he died. Maybe you do. I think your father graduated at 19, but I believe there was some hitch about it, and he didn't get his degree 
Wasn't there some stock, so you won't  have to bear the expense of the $150? I'd be sorry to not have helped you out. I do not question your judgement, Dearie, but I hate to think that came out of your earnings.

until a year or two later. But I'm not sure. Some faculty quarrel, I believe, and jealousy on the part of other professors. He was always a brilliant student, especially in literature and languages. Greek, Latin and especially French. Not at all given to athletics as an incident that happened when he was 13 or 14 proved. He dragged a heavy post for a long distance to make a baseball bat and it gave him an attack of pleurisy that almost cost him his life. (Papa said he was 10 yrs. old at that time) I'm afraid there is very little of this that you can use in an obituary, but it may interest you. I don't know that he even told you his story that shows his whimsical humor. It happened in the grade school when all pupils were obliged to sing in unison. He had absolutely no singing voice, and knew it, so didn't sing. He was reprimanded, but he remained, apparently, obstinate. For explanation, he quoted "I'm saddest when I sing", and it brought down the house. I forget what his punishment was, but that was the only time he was ever punished. Time paid no attention to the item. They belittle all items that have anything to do with socialism, Marxism, Communism, etc. so I wasn't surprised. So glad you have a considerate boss. Don't work too hard! Glad you like Strange Fruit. The next book is "The Firing Squad" which I'll pay for, for you. The membership requires purchase of 4 books a year, and I've had my 4. Lucy sent me The Rains Came. Love to all, Mother.

4 a.m.  June 24, 1944
Darling Lafern:

 I've decided to go to Highlands for 3 or 4 weeks.  It is awful hot here every day, 94º on the porch and no rain.  All my renters urge me to go, especially Mrs. Wells.   She says she will look after everything take care of the cat in her confinement (July 16) and anything else she can do.

Mrs. May Walden
420 West Bell Street, Box 853
Avon Park, Fla.
July 18, 19744 - 
Darling Tafern:
I'm glad I didn't go to the Highlands. I'm having fun writing to the Tampa Times, getting replies, and then making replies to them - Have just finished a reply to a Lakeland woman who asked me when Earl Browder or the Communist Party ever put the interest of the U.S. above that of Russia? I replied that as she "probably knows, the Communists have always been Internationalists and their interest in the welfare of the Soviet people has always been equal to their interest in our own people. Not one above the other, but each for the other - Not competition, but cooperation. Any other questions?" I've been working hard over the peaches from my little tree. They rot around the pit, and it's lots of work getting them ready to can. I now have 6 pints canned. And there are more to do tomorrow. Midge had 4 kittens yesterday morning while I was

doing the washing. She chose the bottom part of the old Frigidaire and had one young one when I decided it was too dirty a place. So I brought out the nice clean box I had fixed for her in my room by the desk, and put it in the corner of the garage by the o.f. and transferred her and the infant. She took it all right, and the 3 others came along in due time. More drowning! Oh dear - I think I'll have Shinola spayed. Only it will be a lot of trouble to take her away to have it done. A card from Vadine said they had Hubert's father in another hospital and he is better - Herbert got an extension of his furlough (my arm sticks to the desk and it's hard to write) for 10 days. So they will be here next Saturday. Another letter from Helen - maybe I mentioned it. Marcel is in a Rest Home somewhere in England. It has been thundering but no rain to speak of. Mrs. May Walden
420 West Bell Street, Box 853
Avon Park, Fla. 
July 10, 1944 - 
Darling Tafern:
Got home just ahead of a storm. The $50 came Sat. but couldn't get it until this aft. The bank was closed so I couldn't do what I mean to with the money - invest in war bonds. There is no use dreaming and speculating about going anywhere. I thought of going to Green Cove Springs - near Jax - for a little trip after I had cancelled my reservations for a room and board in Highlands. But I find the same difficulty. I can buy a ticket, but I may have to stand part way. I'd have to leave here at midnight, reach G.C.S. at 4a.m. leave there at midnight and get here at 7 a.m. and wait from 1 1/2 to 2 1/2 hours in Haines City. When I contrast that discomfort with the quiet & conveniences of my own home, I gladly stay here. So I hope you will not be impatient with me 
on side:
got back Look for them Wednesday. Had no ice over Sunday. I was bathing when the ice man came and didn't hear their call - Today I showed him the buzzer and told him to ring that when he couldn't rouse me otherwise. So glad you had so many holidays and a good visit with the kids. Can almost taste that cherry pie! Mr. Wells just finished painting the garage Sat. aft. It looks nice. Much love to all, Mother.

Your letter came yesterday with a small package and letter from Frank. I suppose Dos and Ann are freezing somewhere tonight on the way down. Dear Editor:
I have just received a letter from Central Illinois under date of July 23 - '51 that may interest other oldsters who have young relatives just committed to training for the "police action" in Korea. As you've probably heard thirty thousand soldiers were evacuated from Fort Riley, Kansas, to escape the flood waters. Donald was one of them. They worked in water and mud above their knees in a vain attempt to build the dykes higher. Pillow cases and mattrass covers from their cots were used as sandbags. Now they are camping in pup tents in the hills where it's cold and foggy. Technically  we're not "at war" so the Government gives only one complete uniform. The boys must buy all replacements and extras (socks, belts, shirts, ties, shaving equipment, shine kits, towels, laundry and bath soap) themselves, pay own laundry, pressing and cleaning bills, fresh white towels for daily inspection, etc. They don't have passes to the theatres, etc., and they must buy their stationery, stamps, ink, etc. Mail comes through seven to ten days late. One mess truck feeds each three thousand soldiers: two lean meals of poor quality a day. They're hungry all the time. We've sent food but they're slow getting through to him. Veterans can scarcely believe that most of the present soldiers pay goes for so many things they got free. It seems like a money-making racket for schemers. Sorry, but I felt you'd share my feelings. Love, Dorrie" This recital is only a small part of what thousands of our boys are going through. May Walden.

before she went for Bill. You are probably pounding along between Atlanta and Chattanooga by now. Mrs. May Walden
420 West Bell Street
Avon Park, Fla.
8 a.m.
Friday Feb. 6. 1953.
Darling Tafern:
Yours with chks from Mrs. Grote and yours from Harold, also card from Sherry and Charles (identical with the one I rec'd several days ago) came promptly. Have credited Mrs. Grote's chk to Mrs. Marshall's basket. Thanks for everything. 
Mr. Marshall valiantly picked and I packed and he fastened the bsks Wed. & Thurs. eves after work and we finished up two this morning, so they all go off this morning except three, Mrs. Kapp's, Norine's & Clara's that went yesterday. The ones to collect for are Thomas, Castle, Sandy, Snow, Ichiba, Carlson, & McCall. I gave each of you half g.f. and half navels. The Kings are not full flavored yet, to my notion, so will send them later. I gave Mr. Marshall a bu.
Forgot to say Cora Wray came over Thurs. a.m. with one of her renters, and they picked up a lot of fruit. then C - stayed until after dinner - She helped pick enough oranges so I finished 2 bskts then Mr Patton came after her. We were disap't that he came as soon as we expected to have the whole day together. We see each other so seldom for a good visit.

9:15 a.m. August 2, 1954 -
Darling Tafern:
Ward just appeared and paid $6.40 due on last (July) payment. He apologized for Murl that she hadn't stopped to do it before she left when on her vacation - So they are about to get things fixed up now to transfer the old cottage to a young family by the name of Singleterry and take the Singleterry trailer as part payment. Ward had on new clothes, shoes, etc and acted like $1,000,000. He hopes to get matters settled in a day or so. Later. He came back in aft. to have receipt altered to $46.40 as he forgot that. Yours of 30th came this morning. So glad the fruit proves satisfactory in every way. No, I didn't make the little mat. I found it at the Davis Dimestore. Yes, I did make the little tray. Longleaf pine needles were plentiful then, but the trees are about extinct now. Glad the M.&L.'s didn't bring the white kitten. It will be much happier at near home. I'm sure you will enjoy the walks with Mitzie, and I hope they will have a fine vacation. The exchange of presents was very pleasurable, I'm sure the dining room table must look swell with it's lace tablecloth. Yes, I've thought of the Metamora paper but rejected it on acc. of Frank. He and everybody, wd be amazed that I don't take him to occupy so attractive a domicile. No, I haven't seen the Perrys nor heard anything lately. I always send you Mrs. P.'s letters that I answer at once. I wear my moccasons, often without stockings, nearly all the time and my callouses have all but disappeared. I manage to cut my own toenails, though it is pretty hard to do, so I don't need a chiropodist. Saw Mrs. Riffle this aft. and she improves, "but is ok, so weak".

To celebrate your b.d. I put your picture on the radio, went out and gathered a little boquet of pentas, verbenas, 2 rain lilies and some rose geranium and put it in a little white vase beside the picture so I could look at it and talk to you all day. I got a lot of pleasure out of it. Then I meant to write out my recollections of the Day, 60 years ago. But I'll do it now. It was a very hot day. For "hired girl" I had Anna - who left Mrs. Gary Wheaton (Mrs. Judge) to come to me, as it was impossible to get a good girl. I think we paid her $12.00 per week. She was very neat, willing and efficient. I knew before we got up that morning that I was in for it that day but I said nothing to Papa as I didn't want him worrying all day. He had enough to worry about with his business. I kept about, not too uncomfortable, until about 4 p.m. when I had Anna telephone him to bring Dr. Martin out with him. Being old college friends they had a good time eating dinner together. About the time dinner was over I began to feel pretty bad. They hurried upstairs and jested while giving me attention. One remark that Papa made always stuck with m. It was apprepo of sterilizing something and he said even the dish-cloth had to be sanctified - he laughed considerably over that. Your head was born before Dr. Martin realized it. She disputed me when I told them you were coming and I said sharply "But I know better" So she hurried to receive you and Anna took care of you until Dr. M. could. The afterbirth came quickly, tho painfully too, and the affair ended happily. Anna staid until Mother came. She staid 6 weeks and we got Cousin Carrie who staid nearly - we quite awhile. We had a black cocker spaniel Papa named Puck. He followed Mother onto the train one day. The conductor put him off at Lombard and we never saw him again - Much love, Mother.

Your letter with H.'s check here yesterday. Thanks as always for check. so glad you succeeded in getting Max to take you to Brookfield. I just know how much you enjoyed it. Mrs. May Walden
420 West Bell Street
Avon Park, Fla.
October 4, 1954.
Darling Tafern:
Congratulate you on being chosen to take Mrs. Castle's place while she is on vacation. Your letter with 5.00 enclosed here last Wed Thanks very much for both. That day I spent with Cora Wray from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. at the library sorting out photographs to be displayed. She came home with me and we worked until nearly 11 p.m. mounting some in our album. She called taxi to get home. She has bright idea of offering to school kids prized to the movie for those who can identify their parents or g-parents in the photos. It has been something of a struggle for her and me to get these photos displayed again. Our young president Paul Jordan, not a forceful personality, argued for a speaker instead. He wrote 2 or 3 weeks ago to Mr. McKay the T.T. historian, who edits a whole page for every Sunday, to address our O.A.C. The Executive Com. met here last Tues. and 
Your letter with H.'s check just here. Thanks always. Will not try to ans. this last letter this a.m. Lena here. Letter & m.m.s. of Eleanor Farrar's trip came also. Will save the m.m.s. for you to read when you come.

he hadn't heard a thing from McKay - as I had predicted he wouldn't. so our program is lagging. Cora is making up for it by her activities, and she says the response is great. Byrum had planned a short paper on the disappearance of certain varieties of palms and other things, but the proposition wasn't brought up. so we won't have that. I had proposed that we have a program on the history of the Mall with old timers giving reminiscence of the development. That was shoved aside by Paul wanting McKay - Our secretary Mrs. Mary Reed is one that can never "get going", so no notice was written for last Friday's Sun, until Wed. a.m. when I wrote out a few lines and telephoned them to the society editor. It got in in a very inconspicuous place. I looked the paper over twice before I found it. Since that I've written something more and am sending it in this a.m. with a letter to give it a prominent place on the front page if no one else sends in something better. As I'm not on the Ex. board

and I don't know how to patch - also I hate it! I'm making Frank buy his own food - mostly entire wheat bread, jam and sliced baloney. He shut himself up in his room, turned on the electric heater until the room reached 72 degrees then shut it off for awhile. He leave the light on nearly always when he leaves his room. I went to a funeral yesterday aft. left him sitting on the porch. He was still there when I got back, and the light was still on in his room. I told him he'd have a fine electric bill to pay. 420 West Bell Street
Avon Park, Fla.  
8:25 p.m.
Friday Feb. 11, '55
Darling Tafern,
So much to tell, - if you were only here! The Welfare lady from this district came day before yesterday - or was it yesterday? Yes, it was, and she staid until noon. Her object was, to find out for the Welfare head in Eureka just how much it takes for Frank and me to live on, so he can cut Frank's check the next months. I co operated the best I could, so I expect it will be cut $20.00 at least - F.'s rent at Mrs. Kran's. Frank took little part in the interview, but I tried to get across to him the important parts of it. He told Mrs. Williamson that whatever she and I arranged wd be all right with him: that he tries to make the best of things. The bad checks are beginning to come in. I gave him the electric bill to pay as he runs the heater in his room when he feels too cool, leaves the lights on in his room, etc etc. He made out a check for the Power Co. and it bounced. So I paid it today without telling him anything about it - There is to be one

420 West Bell Street
Avon Park, Fla.  
Mrs. Charlie Krause has had another stroke and no one knew about it for two days or more. The newsboy found two papers hadn't been picked up, so they got in somehow and found her incoherent and helpless. Saw her yesterday aft at Walker Memorial, and she looks mighty bad - shiny skin, very weak, etc. Also saw Mrs. Mizelle, undertakers wife, a very sweet little body she had had a kidney removed, getting on fine - Mrs. Able, Francis Shockley's  M -in-l also in hosp. but I didn't see here. In fact, forgot she was there. By- came in one day this week with a gift of avocadoes. Very busy with fruit, and no time to make any plans. Lucille, F.'s widow, and her mother have bought out the Kiddie Korner - putting a mtg.on Mrs. A.' s property, to buy it, and a Mrs. King, a divorcee is to run it. Mr. Gr - came early this week with chk for $45.50 and a strictly business-like account of the finances that he handed over to keep and register future amts on. I think he is o.k. Am cramping in legs. Must get to bed - 9:45 p.m. Unheard of hour for me.

Mrs. Renfro said they came over one aft. while I was gone and had a nice little visit with him. She is my finest neighbor, very sympathetic and helpful. She expects her mother over next Saturday for another check up at unclear Hosp. At the same time she is booked by the Band Management to go to Ft. Meyers as Experienced Hostess (chaperone) as Martha (15) is in the band. She is trying to get out of going in order to be with her mother. 
Warmed up this aft and is lovely day. Go to town in a.m. for groceries--
Much love,
Mother

Father had kept him and Ambrose, his older brother and "the old woman", as we always called her after she married Old Yankee Wilson for her second husband some months after Grandfather had died of cancer of the stomach in (?) (see family bible) I knew of the 3rd grave, but don't know its inhabitant. Can't recall the circumstances of its being there, except that he was no relative. The two other graves are friends--at least acquaintances--of Frank's and he got $5.00 apiece for the lots where they were interred, at intervals, I take it, and were friendless and not much account and had to be disposed of somewhere, somehow. The information I was after, I got because I wanted to sell off enough lots to buy Frank a hearing aid. But he says there is so much vacant land that there is no chance for a sale. So ends that! Hope you didn't have to throw out many of the oranges in this last basket, I packed these while he was picking and took only the choicest, Garrett(?) has had 3 or 4 jobs since he has been here. Just this morning took a new one, from the one that he began Monday. Mrs. Renfro told me yesterday that he rented from Toby Renfro.

Mrs. May Walden
420 West Bell Street
Avon Park, FLA. 
May 8, 1955
Darling Tafern
Hope it wasn't so cold with you folks today as the weather man told about. Am thinking of you as being at Marion's and having a suitable celebration. Frank left the house before 7 to go in town to get some pink flowers to celebrate Mother's Day. I told him he should have white, but he kept saying pink, pink. I told him he couldn't buy anything as the stores were closed. Well he could buy them on the streets. That's the way they did up North. He came back abt 9:30. Nothing more said about Mother's Day. "Never? lookin' at some more of this god-forsaken town. They had rain over that part, as you didn't have any here" - Had canned chicken fricassee and a strawb short cake. After dinner we had another

bout over sheets. Wanted me to take all of mine away so when he leaves he will have what's his and none of mine--The other morning he came out mad. He'd like to know where in hell all his towels had gone. Couldn't find a damned one in his room. Told him I didn't know. I hadn't had any of his. Probably he had packed them--"Well I didn't think I was that crazy." I said Well you are just that crazy." He unpacked his trunk and found them--and some of mine! All I'm afraid of is, the Eureka outfit will insist upon his staying another month to use up the aid check they sent. Mrs. Guerndt came yesterday with my monthly payment 42.50 + 2.19 interest. 44.69 yesterday a.m I broke the plastic rim of my glasses. I hunted up a pair I got about 30 years ago and read all afternoon after my nap and finished Memories. am using them to write this, so you can see my eyes  haven't changed much. These are not the ones I wore when Dr. Kesert examined me, I think.

7:20 a.m. Lena comes today. (Black girl who helped Mother wash & clean) Yesterday aft. Mr. Renfro came in for a call. During the conversation he told a joke on himself. He had thought all along that you had no children. Told his wife that you had married an old man and you had never raised any children. She laughed at him and put him straight. All closets empty ditto bureau drawers, except for last minute packing--

Tom came home yester am with a cactus pod on his flank and 2 thorns between his shoulders.  Extracted all quickly and he seemed none the worse.  I put the pod in the stove with newspaper and burned it up.
Am in the dining r00m with the heater beside me and----- fire in living room.  Heated kitchen with small heater while I a brfst, so things are ok.  The Rimfros have lately put in gas to heat their room and I fins their excuse has been much more ---- mine and they shut off the heat in much the same way I do.
Your letter with Maxine's enclosed came Tuesday.  Have ---- her letter and wrote her I'd be very glad to have her  come when you do.  Complimented her letter and urged her to write after.  I certainly look forward

to getting acquainted with her.  To me she seems full of promise.  Sorry I can't see Junior too.  Very --- with your acc. of visit with Harveys.  They must have a very swell establishment but why more room with nobody but the two of them?
The "deal" about Mrs. Hutchinson's property fell thru.  Her son in law referred me to the real estate man and the Renfros had already contacted him, viewed the place and decided not to invest.  Mrs H wants cash and also the house is larger than Dorothy wants.
Had a card from Ann McKauer, no letter.  But Mrs. Byer got a letter with herd telling about your visit some praise of me and saying the town doesn't appreciate me.  Nothing has ever been done about the AP History except refer it to a committee of the City Improvement Organization.  I take it, no money.
The Tribune announces that the Negro Irvin, whose case has been for several years before the public as a false charge of rape, the he will not be executed but have a life sentence.---which according to the law can be ended in six months.  The same sheriff who denied white schools to the Platte children, Willis McGall, is the one who shot Irvin and killed his companion.  Much Love, Mother

Dec. 26, 1955
DArling Jaferee,
Yours with P.O. order for $22.00 and ---- for Frank Reude, Dubbs, Malealu, and Clarke, plus your fine letter came Saturday.  With the exception of basket for Malele- still to be picked- all other were sent last Monday Dec. 19.  Also sent- Maro. news day caolect and yours.  Other prepaid.  DOn't send any more money and no more orders except for gifts.
Had a lovely and most interesting time at Miss Slaughter's and Mr. Catlieu.  Mr. Slaughter and his wife came for me at one Pm.  The hostesses greeted me warmly and almost at once the feast began.  First cocktails, 3 of tomato juice, 2 or port wine, accompanied with crackers and some kind of fish mixture about as big and shaped like a thimble- is that what is called a chef d'oeuvere?  This was passed around and we got rid of it very leisurely-
Then seated, we had in g.f. skins the pieced of g.f. sweetened and a dark cherry- very tasty.  Mr. Slaughter had taken off his coat for it was 80 on my porch while I was sitting in the

sun waiting for them.  In shirt sleeves he began carving after finishing his g.f.  Then the plates were piled with the sliced turkey, dressing, mashed white and candied sweet potato, sweetened cooked apple.  Con't know how it was prepared but it was awful good as was everything.  Never tasted better turkey, it was delicious!  Their giblet gravy was paired i cranberry jelly, olives, celery and radishes.  I omitted the olive and c and r.  Mrs. Leatlier is a slow eater and we kept pace with each other after everybody else had finished.  The the table was cleared and I had a lovely steamed pudding with lemon sauce.  That sound too Plebian for it was an aristocratic version of a fine dessert.  
Mr. Slaughter soon betook himself to his sisters bed while we women both talked and they quizzed me so I told them the story of Uncle John's living with mother and me, his taking my (his) auto when I was in Chicago hospital, his oil wells, my work with the library, etc.
Altogether  it was quite a but of family history that I never dwell upon to my neighbors, but I enjoyed telling it to them for they were so sympathetic and respionsive to my bits of vigorous language.  Mrs. Slaughter went to occupy the bed after my recital and Mr. Slaughter and Miss Avis took me home about 4:30.  I had expressed a desire to go at 3:30 but they urged that I had nothing to go home for. They ll

You write of dyeing the fruit "the way they have done in Calif."  I must admit and condemn Florida for having- and still does - the same crime.
Yes I enjoyed very much the Florida article in Time.  One man, don't remember who or what he is, wanted the Govt. to forbid the circulation of that copy of Time, and I forget his silly reason now.

to Cora's and started back while was at Miss SLaughter's as we had a little talk just before they drove off, then Cora continued the talk after.  The problem of the little children is still unsolved but will have to be in January.  Larrie is to be operated on early Tuesday tomorrow morning, but they hadn't told the poor kid.  XXX  Had a little talk with Miss Slaughter thanking her again and I read that paragraph to her that you wrote about your Registrar party and your playing for the community singing both times.  Mis. S. said I was so welcome and glad I could come.
Where did you  have your Christmas dinner?  You mentioned ?- coming Christmas Eve, but nothing further except Martha thanking for Tommy's book.
Today is grey, cloudy but not cold.  Yesterday was one of our ideal days.  I have no fire, and each cat has his own favorite places, Tom on the sewing machine, Jerry in rocking chair by empty stove and Laddie on my bed.  Wish I could find a nice home for Jerry.  He is a lovely, handsome cat and lets me handle him now, but the others pick on him and spit in his face.  He is wonderful to them, kisses them always when they meet and wants to love them.
Happy New Year!
